metadata.Title: CVE-2017-16879 on Ubuntu 16.04 ESM (xenial) - negligible.
metadata.Description:
Stack-based buffer overflow in the _nc_write_entry function in tinfo/write_entry.c in ncurses 6.0 allows attackers to cause a denial of service (application crash) or possibly execute arbitrary code via a crafted terminfo file, as demonstrated by tic.

Update Instructions:

Run `sudo pro fix CVE-2017-16879` to fix the vulnerability. The problem can be corrected
by updating your system to the following package versions:

lib32ncurses5 - 6.0+20160213-1ubuntu1+esm2
lib32ncursesw5 - 6.0+20160213-1ubuntu1+esm2
lib32tinfo5 - 6.0+20160213-1ubuntu1+esm2
lib64ncurses5 - 6.0+20160213-1ubuntu1+esm2
lib64tinfo5 - 6.0+20160213-1ubuntu1+esm2
libncurses5 - 6.0+20160213-1ubuntu1+esm2
libncursesw5 - 6.0+20160213-1ubuntu1+esm2
libtinfo5 - 6.0+20160213-1ubuntu1+esm2
libx32ncurses5 - 6.0+20160213-1ubuntu1+esm2
libx32ncursesw5 - 6.0+20160213-1ubuntu1+esm2
libx32tinfo5 - 6.0+20160213-1ubuntu1+esm2
ncurses-base - 6.0+20160213-1ubuntu1+esm2
ncurses-bin - 6.0+20160213-1ubuntu1+esm2
ncurses-examples - 6.0+20160213-1ubuntu1+esm2
ncurses-term - 6.0+20160213-1ubuntu1+esm2
Available with Ubuntu Pro (Infra-only): https://ubuntu.com/pro

notes.Note: seth-arnold> The Debian bug suggests tic(1) is the only caller, in which case this would be a 'low' bug; I couldn't quickly verify this claim.

criterions.comment: ncurses package in esm-infra/xenial was vulnerable but has been fixed (note: '6.0+20160213-1ubuntu1+esm2').
